Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Postseismic deformation of the Izmit-Duzce, Turkey earthquake sequence: implications for the mechanics of the earthquake cycle and rheology of the continent
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research will provide an important set of observations on the nature
of the earthquake cycle for a major continental strike-slip fault with direct implications for earthquake
mechanics, estimating earthquake repeat times, crust and upper mantle rheology as a function of the state
of stress, and interaction between earthquake processes and regional tectonics.
Broader Implications: This case study provides information on the mechanics of continental strike-slip
faults in general, including the San Andreas Fault, earthquake and tsunami hazards in the greater
Istanbul area, and opportunities for international scientific collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last century there has been a progression of large earthquakes rupturing the North Anatolian Fault (NAF) in Turkey. These earthquakes have occurred in an east to west progression along the NAF. The latest in the progression was the M7.6 Izmit earthquake in 1999, which resulted in over 17,000 fatalities. Months later, the M7.2 Duzce earthquake occurred to the east of the Izmit rupture. The Izmit earthquake ruptured over 100 km of the NAF, and left the NAF under the Sea of Marmara an ongoing seismic risk to the Istanbul metropolitan area. GPS observations over three years following the Izmit earthquake revealed transient deformation, which has been attributed to postseismic creep on the NAF and deeper viscoelastic deformation. Subsequent GPS observations indicated that the postseismic deformation was continuing, and that there was an unexpected north-south deformation across the Sea of Marmara. Such transient deformation could have implications for the manner in which stress is transferred to the NAF west of the Izmit earthquake. In many ways the NAF is analogous to the San Andreas fault in California, and the 2010 M7.2 El Mayor-Cucapah (EMC) earthquake in Mexico provides an analogue to the Izmit postseismic scenario. The EMC earthquake was followed by transient deformation across southern California, a region of several faults that have not ruptured in the last century.

The goal of the project was twofold. First, our collaborators extended the GPS displacements time-series past the previously available three years of data. Of the GPS monuments in the vicinity of the Izmit rupture, seven cover the Izmit postseismic period to mid 2013 and more than 20 monuments were installed after 2008, while the remaining monuments only recorded deformation over the three years following Izmit. Second, we investigated the robustness of the anomalous north-south transient deformation across the Sea of Marmara and the degree to which these GPS observations could constrain lithosphere viscosities. Mechanical models show that viscosity contrasts under the Sea of Marmara could result in a component of north-south postseismic deformation larger than what would be expected if the viscosity was laterally homogeneous. In order to the address the question of the uniqueness of inferred viscosity contrasts from the geodetic data, we developed a method to invert postseismic GPS observations to image viscosities at depth, which we applied to both Izmit and EMC. We found that the GPS data west of the Izmit rupture are unable to sufficiently resolve viscosity contrasts under the Sea of Marmara, in large part due to the lack of pre-earthquake secular velocities at all monuments and lack of measurements over the full postseismic period at the majority of the GPS monuments. Owing to the density of GPS monuments and continuous observations of the Plate Boundary Observatory (PBO), the EMC postseismic deformation over southern California is much better documented than the Izmit postseismic deformation is to the west of the Izmit rupture. With these dense PBO data, we constrained the viscosities of the asthenosphere, mantle lithosphere, and lower-crust under southern California. We also resolved a transient component of viscoelastic deformation in the mantle lithosphere that led to far-field postseismic deformation. Of wider relevance, we found that when postseismic deformation is inverted for both after-slip and lower crustal viscosity in a coupled model, the inferences are biased, with after-slip in the lower-crust being over-estimated and lower-crust viscosity being under-estimated, due to the fact that deep after-slip drives distributed lower-crustal deformation. 

In order to explore the features of the transient postseismic deformation following the Izmit earthquake, we developed a statistically rigorous method to infer time-dependent strain-rates from GPS data. Given the spareness of the Izmit GPS data, both in time and space, it is crucial to have quantified uncertainties on the inferred strain-rates in order to assess what features are robust. The method uses spatiotemporal Gaussian process regression, with a stochastic prior model for the signal and the noise, which is determined objectively with restricted maximum likelihood. Time-varying strain-rates are calculated from a posterior spatiotemporally smooth deformation field using radial basis function finite differences. Our method is robust against outliers and non-spatially-correlated noise. We use compactly supported auto covariance functions, which give rise to sparse covariance matrices, allowing for strain-rates to be estimated from dense GPS data sets on a typical workstation. Exploration of the consistency between the Izmit postseismic strain-rates and stresses inferred from focal mechanisms is ongoing.
